title: Can e-learning replace live classroom education? How and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am by no means an expert on the subject. But I would say that the short answer is "yes", to some extent. As of right now, there is the large MOOC movement and many of the organizations running these MOOCs are pushing to get college-level accreditation. I, personally, think MOOCs are incredible tools for self learning, but in general they are just not university-caliber classes yet. Even if they were properly accredited, I would still choose to take them without credit just to learn any particular subject I wanted/needed to for my own benefit. But that issue of quality is more of a short time issue than a structural one. The real question is whether e-learning will one day entirely replace schools. For this question, I'd say yes (but not ALL schools). Currently, most students only attend college because they "need to" in order to get a job. If hiring managers ever started weighing self-gained knowledge as equal to diplomas, then we would likely see people choosing the cheaper alternative of e-learning. There would still be students who attend real schools for interests in academia and research and/or sports teams, etc , but you would no longer have a catch-all of EVERY student going to college. Assuming that model seems sustainable once underway, the question becomes how do we get the ball rolling? We'd need hiring managers to trust in MOOCs with the same confidence that they trust in college diplomas. That's why I don't think such a change will come anytime soon, necessarily. However, for many fields (Computer Science, for instance) students can demonstrate their knowledge by building projects from courses they've learned. Similarly, there could potentially be certification programs for less project-based fields where a student can learn the material on their own and then sign-up for a test to prove their knowledge. A system like that would have to be gradually introduced. First, employers would like the projects and certifications as happy little additions to a student's diploma. But as time goes on and the certification programs develop legitimacy and credibility, that could cause hiring managers to decide to have faith in students who can clearly demonstrate their requisite knowledge via customized portfolios. Granted, this is all a largely hypothetical of how a friend of mine and I thought e-learning could really "disrupt" schools.

No, it won’t totally replace it, but there will be a lot more of it! For primary school or children aged 4–12. The answer is no, they need structure and routine, their parents might work and they need a place they can go to get out of the house. In short, they wouldn’t be allowed to be left home by themselves and make sure they would do a good job. For Secondary school 12–16 years, again, I don’t think they will be allowed until they possibly reach the final year and if then! Again the obvious reasons are that parents need to have childcare in place if they are to learn from home! As they reach their final years I expect they will offer greater flexibility with the option to do a lesson or two at home. I don’t think they could move solely to online only. It will help in instances where they might only have 1 lesson in a day. This would reduce their commute, cut emissions and save everyone's time. When currently learning in the classroom, I think they will be utilising a lot more online tools, whether that would be YouTube, official content or educational websites and using a lot more learning CRMs where they can track learners, submit homework and upload evidence all in one place. This means that teachers don’t have to mark 30 separate books! For College - I think yes, online learning will take over from a lot of classes. This is the transition to becoming an independent learner. Many are already implementing the learning CRM system but not yet teaching classes that way. I think after COVID-19, I think they will try more classes online so that they can create efficiencies within the college and reduce commutes and time spent travelling. University - This is where they will use it the most. However, the problem here is would you pay 9K for the tuition fee to be educated online? This is where they will balance between online and classroom teaching. I think it is a useful tool to have, and can mean a lot more contact time with students on a personal level or 1–1 for their dissertation, support in the labs and assignments.

E-learning tools provide educators and students with access to resources they couldn’t have had otherwise, no matter their status or location. A philosophy student in England can learn from the top professor a continent away, and can do so in their own time while balancing a full-time job and a family at home. But even though e-learning has become an education equalizer, it’s still not a replacement for the traditional classroom. Sure, the technology is advancing, but it’s not flawless. Just like any new, burgeoning innovation, e-learning faces its own challenges. This, to me, is where e-learning and the traditional classroom will one day form a union: compensating for one where the other lacks. Here’s what I mean. The State of The Traditional Classroom In a traditional classroom, educators will tell you they need to be on their toes, trying to engage their students at every moment. But students don’t always cooperate—maybe they’re bored, zoned out, or too focused on the sun outside to pay attention to math. That lack of engagement is a challenge for the student as well. They can’t hit pause on a teacher and rewind back to the part where they stopped paying attention, which means they’re going to miss out. Accounting for a student’s individual attention span is also an issue in traditional classrooms. Some students fatigue after 50 minutes, others after 15, and there’s no way to adjust for that in a real-time environment. Despite these problems, once the teacher and the student meet in the middle and find that engagement, it’s magic. Being surrounded by like-minded people, actively participating with peers, and seeing students come alive once things click is a social energy you can’t replace—even with AI. The Emergence of E-Learning One of the ways e-learning has tried to mimic the social aspects of a classroom is with tools like messaging boards, Facebook groups, and yes, sometimes chatbots. They give students the sense they aren’t just staring at an empty message board, but they are talking with real people about their homework. Of course, this doesn’t replace talking with peers or having a teacher know your name. Students naturally learn from one another while solving problems and working collaboratively in a traditional classroom. They’re validated and encouraged by face-to-face time with a teacher that doesn’t come from a pre-recorded video. E-learning has yet to find a way to truly imitate that. From the teacher’s perspective, e-learning tools give them precise, clear-cut feedback on how a student is engaging with material. They can see where students get lost in a lesson and grade assignments with the click of a button. A reduced workload allows teachers to flex their skills in other ways—ways that are more beneficial to the students and the classroom. Less hours spent grading workbooks means more time spent engaging each student on an individual level. It’s this combination of customized content and resource management that will allow teachers to lead our classrooms into the future. What The Future Classroom Looks Like These days, more and more students are being driven to self-instruction—either because they can’t afford tuition or are simply excited about a topic. This is where e-learning comes in. If a platform could actually cater content and interaction around the individual user—their speed, their interests, their location—then e-learning could give them the ability to learn whatever they want, from wherever they want. If a student wants to attend Harvard business lectures but lives halfway across the country, then e-learning puts them in the room. True mobility and access to education is the future. But that doesn’t mean we stop empowering our classrooms and teachers. While e-learning won’t replace traditional classrooms, it will change the way we know them today. With improved resources and reduced teacher workloads, classrooms can shift to co-learning spaces. Students can arrive, learn, engage—all at their own pace in a collaborative environment. And that’s the true goal of education: to create the best environment for students to learn.

While I think online learning will certainly expand to fill a large niche, I don’t think it will ever replace the classroom. Even if we could force that to happen, would that really be what we want? The folks I’ve met who champion some computer-based system for all students don’t seem to “get” all students. They’re imagining students of average-to-above average performance and attention who do well to sit for greater or lesser times in front of a computer, be that researching, creating, or even just listening to a teacher. This idea ignores the diversity of learners. I’ve had students who: Have experienced trauma in such a way that online activities are, for whatever reason, a trigger leading to emotional explosions and breakdowns.Are too fidgety and/or distracted to sit in front of a computer for the time needed to do a lesson.Simply learn better with something more concrete than even the cutest and cleverest online manipulative.Need a greater and more immediate back-and-forth communication than online learning can generally give.Do not live in a household that works for online learning. Doesn’t matter what devices the school might provide—it’s just not going to happen in that household.Simply prefer face-to-face interaction.One might argue that ever-evolving online methods could solve these problems, but to what end? Simply to prove that online learning can take over? To dismiss the enjoyment of being present with other humans? To solve a supposed problem? To make all students the same? Some of the best minds in the world still prefer to get together in person to learn and discuss. What’s wrong with that? I do predict a happier, more organic blend of the traditional-enough classroom and online learning, but I don’t think pure online learning will ever become the absolute only.

I believe that our academic institutions will still exist due to our systems of employment. However, those who have studied or taught online realize that it is a better system than the traditional classroom. Learning online is incredibly efficient. In fact, working online, learning online, teaching online, etc. is currently the most efficient method to compartmentalize aspects of your life IF you are willing to stay motivated and be honest with yourself (and your teacher!). You cannot get lazy if you’re shifting your life online: be responsible and self-motivated and enjoy the rewards and convenience. Online learning is not for those who are completing a course because it ismandatory. It is for those who are truly inspired and motivated.  Some advantages of learning online over the traditional classroom: Personal assessment before learning. A good online company or teacher should be able to test your status and pinpoint your strengths and weaknesses, helping to define your study plan and curriculum.Personal attention and feedback. In most online learning situations, it’s just you and the teacher. No distractions, no repeating your classmates’ errors and mistakes, no waiting for others. You get feedback with each step of the journey.Convenience. No, online learning doesn’t mean you can be lazy, or watching TV in the background, it means that you can attend your class regardless of the weather, your vehicle’s condition, traffic and so many other factors. If you travel for work or leisure, you can take classes from the comfort of a hotel or quiet cafe.Record and Replay. This is an advantage that many learners don’t realize or take advantage of. Learning online, students can replay their lesson as many times as they’d like, pausing and re-watching as they wish.Affordability! Many personal teachers and tutors charge high rates as they factor in travel time and lesson preparation. With online learning, you don’t have to pay London, New York or Sydney hourly rates if your teacher is located in another part of the world. Online lessons are very often cheaper, as was in my case. My Own Story Before arriving in China and enrolling in a Mandarin Chinese language course here, I had began my Chinese learning at a community college in the USA. Unfortunately, it was too easy for me to fade into the background. I wasn’t being forced to speak with the teacher each step of the way and I wasn’t getting the personalized feedback that I needed. The speaking tones of Mandarin Chinese were difficult and I was repeating the mistakes of my classmates. I decided to enroll in online lessons. I first took a free online assessment test with a teacher in China. The test pinpointed my strengths and weaknesses and helped me develop a study plan. In just 30 minutes I felt like I’d already make great progress. You asked about efficiency? That 30 minutes was the same as my commute to school. That intro college course I took in the classroom ended up being my last. I was making such good progress with the online lessons that I wasn’t getting enough from the course to continue. Since I was saving some time, I focused on self-study through apps, websites, blogs and textbook. I took additional Mandarin Chinese classes online to help with all levels of my HSK tests. I made such great progress that I changed my life plan and moved to China to finish my degree here. Being a somewhat shy student, online learning really brought me out of my shell and got me speaking. Not just for efficiency, but also effectiveness, I can certainly recommend online learning.

A blended model will emerge offering the best of both worlds to the students. And I think that’s how it should be. Moving exclusively to just one model of learning is not desirable from the point of view of a child’s growth. And we don’t need to create a competition between online and offline teaching. And neither do we want to threaten either the teachers or the organisations which provide online learning solutions. They should complement. Let me tell you how. A teacher walks into her class and spends 30 mins in teaching Newton’s third law of motion to a class of say 25 students. After the class, she opens up her Teacher’s app and allocates a small 20 question test to all her students on the same topic. When the students reach home, there is a notification on their parent’s phone. The notification says that their teacher had today taught Newton’s third law of motion and that they have to do a test. So, as guided, the students take the test. Instantly the reports go to the teacher where she sees that out of 25 students, 5 are at 100% mastery, 10 are around 70–90%, 5 are at 60–70% and the rest are less than 50%. She immediately allocates additional tasks or video lessons to the students depending on their mastery level which students are expected to do in the next 2 days. While the teacher in the class moves on to the next task but she is continuously tracking and guiding her students via the app to build mastery over every single topic. Some students do it in 2 days, some take 5. But eventually everyone reaches a level of 100% mastery. Would this have been possible with just the offline mode of teaching? Never. The existing school ecosystem does not allow a teacher the time or the mind space to personalise learning for every child. But an in-home supplemental learning solution can genuinely complement her efforts in the class. In one of the responses, there is a mention about rural students and that they would be left behind. Rather I feel they are the one’s who can benefit the most and hence come up. Yes, we will have to bridge the digital divide and I think the speed at which it is happening, days are not far when even the rural most kid in the country will be able to use digital for learning and growth. So to summarise, as a part of education ecosystem, we should derive the best of both forms of learning and build a process where online learning can support our teacher’s efforts inside the classroom.

I have attended online courses which have been great and others which have had a large amount of students not finishing the course. Online studying is a great supplement for traditional learning with a teacher and live interaction between students and the teacher. For a motivated student, online courses are mostly really good. I know a lot of young people who have studied a language by internet with a great determination. Replacing schools with online courses has problems. There are a lot of students who need the help of the teacher to keep themselves motivated and to grasp the content. So, I don’t believe in the total collapse of the educational system. I think the system may need to develop to become more efficient and motivating for contemporary learners, though. The digitally “savant” generation is very diverse and the education system needs to be able to serve all of the students: those fluent in digital literacy, those lacking the basic reading and comprehension skills, those struggling to find a place in this complex and frightening world, those talented in peculiar fields. Technology in the classroom may help in individualising the tasks and in making the lessons more interesting. But what the young people really need is interaction with caring and competent adults and with their peers. That is a key to mediate not only facts or theories but also the core of human culture as a developing, living, existentially meaningful entity. The reason for a long education years lies in the human evolution. Learning takes time. The more complex our culture the more the students need time to really learn both the tradition and the technologically new human tools and knowledge. If they are to develop a sense of character and moral integrity, most of the students need adult guidance. I am not saying some children or teens could not learn without schools. But I argue, that online education (while being necessary and important) can’t replace real life connections and human interaction which I see at the heart of a fulky functional school for any age.

No completely sure , here’s some of my observation Web-based education technology has seen both promising and lackluster results in terms of adoption and course completion rates; however, online education proponents assure us that the traditional classroom is on the cusp of a dramatic change. Over 300 lecture hours at Berkeley, Harvard and MIT are available, for free, on YouTube. MOOCs are designed to be free for participants and open to anyone, and other online learning platforms are made inexpensive for the end user. The online medium is scalable because of its reduced overhead compared with brick-and-mortar schools. Despite a record high in online enrollment, the EdX analysis conducted by MIT and Harvard revealed some surprising attrition rates. Of the learners in the study, 95 percent of students dropped their online class before getting a completion certificate. The Babson Research Study revealed that academic leaders are undecided about MOOCs as a sustainable method for offering courses, with most (45.2 percent) being neutral, and the remainder evenly split between the two opposing opinions. Less than three percent of higher education institutions currently offer a MOOC. While 69.1 percent of chief academic officers claim that online learning represents a critical part of their long-term strategy, only 9.4 percent are in the planning stages of implementing a MOOC, suggesting that other types of online education are expected to emerge in colleges and universities. You decide.

I do not think that everything can be taught or learned from sitting in front of a computer screen. Sometimes technology statistics and forecasted numbers would make us think that technology will someday take over the world, but there will always be a place for the classroom. The statistics that we read always give a slightly off-centered reason why e-learning, or online training or instructional design is the way of the future. That is not to say that technology-based solutions are not the way to future success, but that they are not the only means of achieving successful student learning and mastery of the content. Whilst there are many, many credible sites and resources that boast well-backed studies, there always seems to be an audience for classroom studies, students that would rather learn from a teacher they can physically watch present the materials and there will always be a vast following for things that are not electronic. For instance, I am part of a 50s pinup group. This group supports veterans as they are coming home from a war or tour. That is, I am part of a group of woman that dress in attire from the 40s and 50s and greet our veterans after a flight home. The men and women love reminiscing about ‘those days.’ It always brings a smile to their faces. Could we greet the service men and women, especially the decorated war heroes in current fashions? Of course, but oftentimes, the WW1 and WW2 vets get a chance to ‘remember the good ole days.’ Do you remember those days? What made ‘those days’ so special? I use that as an illustration because sometimes what is in someone’s mind can help them recover or cope…or learn. That said, there will always be a place for stand-up teaching by where there is a teacher in front of a classroom. In fact, some subjects are just better off taught or learned in-person. For instance, have you ever tried to take a pole dancing class online? How about kickboxing? How about a (boring) topic like network computing or a complex topic like biology, or animal dissection? Some subjects are too interactive to be fully grasped online. At least the basics are better off learned from an instructor that can help you physically or gauge based on your facial expressions or responses. In summary, even in the age of Youtube, Quora and many other interactive sites, thee will still be a need for and a love of that of which can be taught by a classroom instructor – regardless of the number of students or size of the classroom or facility.

IMO, e-learning MUST displace classroom learning, and quickly.  This is most important in high school and college education.  As in any discipline, there is a scarcity of top practitioners with the skill to make topics understandable, engaging and lasting.  With exceptions, these stars understandably gravitate to school districts or colleges with the most innovative or supportive environments, generous compensation and prestigious brands.  Few budget-strapped urban schools can attract such educators, which degrades the education received by those of lesser means. To de-couple education quality from the learners' financial means, we have to make the best instructors in the world available to all who wish to learn.  That means virtualizing them or otherwise making them scalable online. The medical profession is already going down this road, enabling doctors to collaborate with specialists anywhere in the world -- in real-time.  The legal profession is taking steps in this direction, too, automating much of litigation support to enable experts in small firms to manage cases that previously would have had to been led by huge firms with armies of lawyers to do the document management. E-learning makes knowledge universally available, asynchronous, and inexpensive.   One final driver is the fact that many universities' growth is constrained by the lack of urban real estate.  A couple of years ago, Business Week's cover story was about how universities in densely-populated cities, such as Columbia (NYC), Stanford (SF) and Georgetown (DC), not otherwise known for their technical innovation but unable to grow physically, were forced to embrace e-learning because of this imperative.

Q - Can e-learning replace live classroom education? How and why? Yes, it can, but it’s a bit more complicated than this. We should break the learning phase into 3 steps - pre-class, class and post-class. Pre-class step is when the student sees the subject (or question or problem) for the first time, understands the issue, and maybe gets some background. Sometimes we need to explain why it’s an issue which we bother to think about or need to solve, or why it’s not trivial as we may think. We then may raise few ways to approach and solve the issue, eliminate few and come up with a way (or several ways) which is/are good enough. The class step is the interesting one. The student may want to discuss, debate or ask questions, maybe disagree with what was said in the previous step, hear other opinions, etc. The post-class is what we call practice. Now, the 1st and 3rd steps can (and actually should) be delivered remotely through e-learning. With the proper engaging and interactive e-learning methods, we can make it interesting, fun and even personally adjusted to the student. There must be many little tests in the way, making sure that the student understands everything that was “said”, and we leave no knowledge gaps or misunderstood areas. These tests do not have to be the usual scary exam (and no, calling it “evaluation” or other name will not make it more beloved). It’s a nice interaction, never more than 1–2 together, which does not look like a test. A tutor (teacher) must be in the loop - using technology he/she can review the answers to those tests, see if there are areas that many students misunderstood and students that are struggling. Each failure to fully understand a piece gets additional explanation (built-in the material, no human involvement). The basic idea - we do not leave any student to misunderstand any part of the learned material. The middle step is where communication between students and teacher, and among students, is important. If we can have a physical classroom, that’s when they all meet together. If this is not an option, they “meet” remotely, using technology - small students’ groups between themselves, and a weekly students-teacher virtual meeting. The students already know the material, and the teacher knows whats areas of the subject are less understood and need more explanation. There are tons of details which I left behind, but these are the basics. Hope I made myself clear. Thanks for reading
